text: Couldnt believe I hadnt rated this. Ive had several times. Anyways I remember it being a solid esb beer, but a little malt heavy. There you go.
Pours a nice hazy golden orange color. Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops. Flavor starts malty and the hops kick in, nice crisp bitter finish.
Poured an orangish brown color with aromas of herbs, light malt, some caramel, bitterness, and feint hops. flavors were the same as the aromas, not much bitterness, decent.
Appearance is deep copper to brown in color with slight haze. Malty, nutty, and caramel aroma. Taste is sweet malt with a nice faint backbone of hops to keep it balanced. This is a great ESB.

Reviewed from notes.
This was poured into a pint glass at their brewpub location in the Atlanta airport. This was consumed last September (2013).
The appearance was a nice hazy orange to brown color with a decent looking half fingered white foamy head that dissipated within less than twenty seconds. There was some light lacing arranging itself in no apparent reason as it just sort of danced all around the glass (okay, no worries, I guess).
The smell had the authentic yet slightly typical British malts amplifying some nice light caramel tones.
The taste was mainly sweet and though it seemed like it wanted to steer away from that "British soapiness" usually found in ESBs that most Americans dont like, I still found it. But this doesnt bother me as I understand this is part of the style. No worries.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body and had a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed right on for the style and good for me.
Overall, good ESB, well worthy of having again, now wheres my fish n chips.
Sweetwater did this ESB right. Great malty profile with earthy hops and a dry yeast that adds a little bit of esters to the brew. Not a quaffing beer, but close.
Fine to drink. Nice aroma and fetures too. A little bit too bitter as the beers from this company.

Sampled draught as part of a flight at Dunedin House of Beer on January 19, 2014.Listed as 5.6% ABV.Clear golden color, white head. Hoppy, herbal, some citrus, bitter taste. Bitter, hoppy, fruity aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Hoppy, resin scent.

Crisp amber and deep copper coloured body with a nice two centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of earthy malt, toffee, light hops and a subdued nuttiness thats noticeable at the end. Light to Medium-bodied; Strong toffee and malt flavours with a light dose of english or low alpha acid hops noticeable and a light sweetness as well. Aftertaste shows a bit of earthiness, a good malt and toffee flavour and some very light hops. Overall, not such a great beer - lacking way too much on the hop profile and only showing a little of the earthiness and toffee flavours throughout - not enough complexity. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Palm Beach Gardens for US$1.99 on 30-December-2013 sampled in my hotel room here in Clearwater, Florida on 03-January-2014.

Sweetwater Motor Boat is pretty much average. Not much aroma coming from a dark brown tinted pour. The head is fizzy and doesnt hold very well. Taste is malty with a bitterness that lasts a little too long without any complexity. Motor Boat is ok with a meal but not particularly outstanding on its own.
Good and malty. Pours a light amber color with a fairly weak aroma. Not my favorite beer but definitely drinkable.

In a sampler pack from my son. It poured a clear amber color with a small light tan head. The aroma was slightly fruity and floral with a nice mix of malt and hops. The taste was similar with some pine hops as well and a little bread, fruitiness and resin as the beer warms. It had a light to medium body with average carbonation and a medium to long, bitter finish. Very good.
Bottle: Clear amber color with a small head. Hoppy and fruit aroma of perhaps apricots with a little hairspray. Good hoppy flavor with lots of carbonation. Not bad.
Bottle pours a hazy amber with a short lived off white head. Light toasted malts and plenty of bitterness. IBUs but not much hop flavor. Kind of what I dont like about ESBs in general.
Poured from a bottle it is a clear amber Colorado with a slight head. The stoma is citrus and the taste is grapefruit that lingers on the palate and leaves the taste on your tongue

From a 12 oz bottle shared in Avon NC. Pours a clear amber with an off white head. Fruity hop nose. Flavors of grassy hops, caramel and a touch of honey. Medium bodied, high carbonation, bitter finish.

Bottle--really lovely version of an ESB, found in the seasonal section at Total. Aroma of biscuit and some hops. The color was dark amber with a small head. Looks great in an English Pint Glass. The hops start off the taste without becoming overwhelming and then the soft caramel and toffee taste kicks in. Finish with a bit of hops and lingering sweetness. A charming version of an Americanized ESB. Total wine.
Excellent take on an ESB. Extremely well balanced. Very pleasant booziness.

12 oz. bottle in a trade with Darren. Best by 12/04/2013. Dark amber color with soapy bubbles that laced well. Nose is caramel, toffee and fruity hops. Assertive hop profile for the style! Pine and herbal hops linger on the tongue for a long duration. Just enough caramel malts to provide balance. Roasted grain in a medium body. Exceeded my expectations. But not want you may be looking for in an ESB, very hoppy compared to true English recipes. Nice drink.
Pours a dark amber color. Moderate hop aroma....light citrus, resiny. Flavor is big on the hops for style but enjoyable. Citrus, and some earthy hops. Very enjoyable.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear medium copper with a very thick and billowy off-white head. Amazing, rock hard head retention but somewhat lacking in lacing.

Lots of citrusy American hops in the aroma along with a moderate amount of toasted malt and some caramel. Really nice hops/malt balance here.

Lots of juicy, citrusy hops up front quickly followed by toast and caramel and a touch of roast. Hops are a bit fleeting, though, as they fade away a little too quick as does the malt flavor. What you are left with is a lingering light sweetness and a mild bitterness. It is very pleasant although I wish the flavors were a little more bold.

Overall, a very nice beer from Sweetwater. Really fits the fall season and a nice alternative to pumpkin brews and Oktoberfests.

Smells like the epitome of a ESB. A little malty. A little hops. A little spicy. Looks fine. Pale brown caramel color. Good head retention. Tastes like the smell. Malty, a little bitter. A little spicy. Palate is fine. Smooth. Huh almost a little rubber taste in there. 

Overall I dont really like esbs but this is great for the style. Ive heard great things about sweetwater so I may continue to check them out.

translucent amber with a thick beige head. medium body with medium-high carbonation. seems thin but resinous and foamy, so has a self-conflicting mouthfeel, and gives a sort of awkward and gassy drinking experience.

aroma: citrusy american hops, worty pale and crystal malts.

taste: astringent grain, boiled hop residue (like a hop bag right when its pulled out of the kettle after an hour-long boil), caramel malt, and some yeastiness.

seems like an english recipe and yeast strain, but american grains and hops.

Great aroma of juicy peach and apricot. Slight malt influence with flickers of caramel. Appears as it should tan head a top a burnt orange brown body. Taste is bright fruit with balanced back end bitterness. Very solid esb.
12oz bottle pours a clear, brick red with some cloudy, white head. Nice nose, dried leaves, some fruit, some peach, malt. Flavor is malty, sweet, fruity, light citrus bite. Clean finish.
Bottle from Total wine stuart. pours brown with an inch of khaki foam. a little bit of malt on the nose. Finally a bitter that tastes bitter. Nice hop presence that leaves a gift on the finish. Nice!

This beer was poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass. This beer has a decent appearance with a nice copper color with a decent one finger head and some decent lacing to it. The smell is the worst part of the beer (thankfully, I dont buy beers to smell them) and has a mild bitter and carmel smell to it (would like more the smell to be bitter). The taste of the beer fits well into the ESB style beer, has a great malty, carmel flavor with some great back door bitterness to it. The afterfeel is okay with some mild bitterness and some carmel flavoring to it. Overall, I wish this beer was distrib uted in my area, but will hopefully be picked up and sent back to me upon its future release....I look forward to it again.

translucent amber, thin white head falls to a few large clumped bubbles. Hoppy nose, light caramel malt, oily. Sticky sweet flavor, orange candy mid, thick through the oversweet end. Oily, coats lips, sticky and burdensome. Started nice but fell apart.

12oz bottle, thanks nmann08. ASmall off-white head atop crystal clear dark amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some orange, light spicy, honey. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, bread, some orange, spicy. Light-medium body.
Golden pour. Bready malt, toast, and earthy, citrusy hops on the nose. Flavor profile is balanced between toast and American hop varieties. Medium body. Good, very good.
Bottle. Poured a golden, slightly copper color with a solid, wispy head. Aroma was notes of sweet malts, hops, a touch earthy notes. Sweet notes of hops, malts, sweetness, refreshing.

Got at Krogers on Broadway in Fountain City.

Dark Amber. Long, beige head. Aroma: Grapefruit, earthy hops, perfume. Flavor: Same with some caramel, dry. Bitter finish.

As to the comment, I am an "Old Sailor" and I approve of this brew.
Bottle. Served without a glass, so I cant see the color - and no head, of course. Aroma is a tough one too, maybe light grass? Taste is lemon, straw. Inoffensive.
Woody, nutty, malty with a very nice crisp finish. Hints of bitter hops come in at the end. Very nice.

Appearance: not quite transparent brown color, pours with a medium tan head that fades quickly

Aroma: butter, dough, faint, cream

Taste: darker roasted malt, not quite coffee but close, very faint hops taste and then bitterness on the finish

Palate: lively carbonation, light mouthfeel, bitter aftertaste

Overall: probably not a beer is pick out generally but not bad, 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweetwater Motor Boat has a thin-to-medium, cream-colored head, a mostly clear, copper appearance, some bubbles, and moderate lacing left behind on the glass. The aroma is very citrus oriented (think grapefruit), with background sweetness. Taste is of grapefruit, hop oil, lots of bitterness, a touch of caramel, white bread, and white bread crust. Mouthfeel is light and watery, with a bit of slickness, and Sweetwater Motor Boat finishes semi-dry, refreshing, drinkable, and not like an ESB. Although it does not fit the claimed style, it is still very good. RJT
Toffee colored pour. Big off-white head. Plenty of lacing. Big hop aroma. Oranges and malt. Malty up front that quickly fades to a nice crisp hop flavor. Nice.

Draft at the ATL airport on layover. Nice copper color with an off-white head, and a pleasant toast and green hops aroma. Enjoyable balance between sweet and bitter with a medium body and a clean finish. Cant pick a much better brew to kill time with in the airport.

Bottle. Clear dark amber, white head and some minimal lacing. Aroma is floral, citrus and pine. Taste is sharply bitter to start followed with a nice bready malt backbone. Nice crisp mouthfeel. Reminds me a bit of a rye IPA; solid brew.

EB: 11.10.13.
Light brown, deep amber hue. White head, adequate. 
Root beer, sarsaparilla.
Candy caramel, brown malt. 
Americanized ESB.

Solid low ABV offering from Sweetwater. Drank a half serving at lunch. Pours clear amber with light head. Scent is a touch of grain with a hint of citrus. Taste is mildly sweet with crisp bitter finish. Light-Medium body and somewhat flat. Would like to try this brew on cask. Draft - Brick Store Pub - Decatur, GA

Appearance: 1 fluffy cream colored head, recedes at a moderate rate with lots of lacing. Amber color with a cloudy appearance (probably hop sediment in suspension), significant carbonation bubbles streaming up.

Aroma: Pine and citrus hops dominate the smell. There is some detectable malt as well in the background (a bit of earthy, bready odor).

Mouthfeel: light to medium bodied, just slightly sticky, highly carbonated in the mouth (almost like drinking a cola), somewhat dry finish.

Flavor: Fairly well balanced as the hops dominate from start to finish  pine, citrus, and floral, even a hint of English type earthy hops. The biscuit quality of the malt helps to even out the taste and there is some caramel sweetness also.

Overall: Great job Sweetwater!

Bottle.  Ok this is not a great ESB.  Its a decent beer but it really sits on the fringe of the style if it sits within it at all.  Look at the ABV alone.  I think there is a slight north american skew in the rating system on this one.

Bottle. Pours murky light amber with a thick creamy head. Faint aroma - clean hops with a hint of spice. Very mild flavor - this is supposed to be a bitter? Smooth, clean, slightly sweet, flavor of hops, some grass and a hint of orange. Tiny bit of bitterness in the aftertaste. Sweetwater has decided to redefine ESB I guess.

The palate to Sweetwater Motor Boat Ale is everything I would expect in an American Pale Ale, but since its an ESB (extra special bitter), its not exactly what I want in the style. Thats not to say Im all about conforming to style, far from it, but theres something to be said for expectation. This beer is nothing like Wells Bombardier or Fullers ESB, and is more akin to any standard American Pale Ale.

I received a 12oz bottle in a beer trade with Ding. I poured it into a nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Hazy brown/burgundy hue. Forms a large, beige, frothy head which is slow to dissipate and leaves plenty of lacing on the glass.

Smell: Light citrus notes, especially orange. A sweet candy scent and a hint of pine needles.

Taste: Sharp bitterness right away with a light sweet orange candy flavor through the middle. The hops impart a significant bite and dry astringency throughout the second half of the swig. The aftertaste is a lingering bitterness but nothing intolerable. Id definitely prefer a stronger, more balanced malt character, but the by-the-book hop profile is at least satisfying. 

Drinkability: This is a perfectly medium-bodied beer all around. A crispness to the body thats not overly fizzy. It goes down smooth and is actually quite refreshing while in the mouth, though it is rather drying afterwards. Sweetwater Motor Boat Ale has a lot of flavor for 5.6% ABV and sits much lighter on my system than most beers of that potency. Ideal for dinner, but too strong to session.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle. Murky amber orange pour with a smaller white head. Floral, citrus, and some cracker. Solid.

12 ounce bottle pours copper with a off-white head.  Aromas of bread, malts and a bit of floral.  Taste is the malts and a little bitterness from the hops.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle poured into an imperial pint glass. Pours a dark orange with a small white head and lots of lacing. Huge aroma and taste of citrus and hops that is as strong as an IIPA. A little overwhelming on the citrus though. Finish is dry and bitter, as it should be. Palate is medium  and creamy. Very nicely done.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2012 Medium copper color.  Nice malty presence in the background, mostly bread with a bit of crust.  Some earthy hops there as well with a slight floral character.  Flavor has a nice bitterness to back up the bread.  Medium body and a bit chewy.  Well done ESB.

Floral aroma with bitter front and end, sweet notes in the middle. Crisp amber. Good color. Good ESB. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2014 Bottle..Another very good beer from Sweetwater. Extremely floral with the hops standing out. Nice lace. A slight bit murky amber. One of the better American ESBs for sure! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap. Deep amber with small head. Very good bitter. Big english hops. Excellent ESB.

Tap. Pours hazy amber brown with a small tan head and some lacing. Aroma is grass, hay, caramel. Taste is about the same, herbal and with a light rye spiciness, lightly sweet, light bitter, lightly astringent.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2013 Rerate

9/2012 aroma not what id remembered.  Needs more aroma. I have to drop it from 4.1 to 3.9 

Slight sweet hoppy aroma.  Apearance is amber clear with a good head that fades partially.  Very clean hop malted balance taste.  Easy on the palate of a hophead... hard for others.  I really enjoy this ESBBBBB.

Bottle received via trade with TheBeerSommelier.  Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy white head, medium-short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is fruity, earthy, and herbal hops, biscuit and cereal malt with tropical fruity esters.  Flavor is moderate hops and bitterness, supporting sweet malt with fruity esters and a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

Pint at Tribeca Tavern. Good aroma, sweet, grassy, little bready. Tad hazed brownish orange. Good head and lace. Bitter flavor. Medium body, smooth  creamy mouthfeel. Bitter finish. Its good, wouldnt say it slapped me silly, but solid esb., flavor was  best part.  Nice bitter brew
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours an amber color with an extremely thick white head. Interesting citrus and floral notes to the nose, even with the head. Sweeter than I expected without much bitterness. Interesting brew...

Good bitter bite but little backbone.  I'd recommend this for someone who likes ipa's but want something a little different.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy brownish copper on tap with off-white fluffy head that dissipates to thin film and leaves great lacing. Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, toffee hints, slight piney hop. Taste is similar with a creamy, fuller mouth. Real good, one of the better sweetwater beers.

Pours a clear copper with a sudsy, beige head. Aromas of caramel, earthy hops and yeast. Taste has a fair amount of caramel malts with a bit of grapefruit coming through. Has a bit of stickiness on the tongue and it seems to sweeten as it gets warmer. Not as bitter as I was expecting considering its an ESB but still a rather nice offering.

Bottle - gift from my friend Noel. Amber pour with a tall tan head. Aroma is nutty with earthy hops, spicy hops and caramel. Taste is nutty with strong caramel, toasted grains, toffee, spicy hops and soft earthy hops. Body is medium with soft bubbly carbonation. Ends with more toasted grains, caramel, spicy hops, sweet malt, earthy hops and nuttiness.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber orange with a tan head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has some earthy citrus hops with notes of earthy grain and hay. Flavor starts with earthy hay and grass with a hint of grapefruit in the finish.
Draft.  Pours a burnt orange in color.  Aroma is biscuits, caramel malts with some citrus aroma.  Flavor is caramel malts with a nice balance of citrus hop bitterness.  Good bitter finish.  Nice ESB.
12oz bottle courtesy of drowland.  Amber pour with a finger or two of head. Malt and caramel aroma, sweet malts and hop bitterness taste.  Quality brew, but nothing amaing

Not my thing.  The aroma is floral and hoppy.  The color is a copper to light brown with a thin white head.  The taste is very hoppy but without a distinct flavor profile, just bitter.  The body is medium but with a degree of astringency.  A very bitter somewhat harsh beer.  Sweetwater makes some great beers, just not sure this is one of them.

Pours a hazy caramel/amber color with a medium thin tan head.  Aroma is earthy and malty with light caramel and maple leaf notes.  Flavor follows suit and adds some tea notes...too malty!  Mouthfeel is light and the finish is malty and tastes like tea.

Bottle. Pours amber orange with an off white head. Earthy hoppy aroma, with sweet toffee malts. The flavor has sweet toffee and bready malts with floral and earthy hoppy notes, followed by a medium bitter finish. Not bad.

12 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a bright orange amber color with a small off white head.  The aroma has mildly toasted malt, caramel, and some mild herbal and floral hops.  The flavor has a base of toasted malt, caramel, floral and lightly herbal hops with some fruitiness at the edges.  The bitterness is mild to moderate.  Overall, this was drinkable but not something I would revisit.

12oz bottle.  Red-orange.  Respectable steady beige head.  Big caramel/amber malt aroma, thick crystal/specialty malts.  Kind of watery, soapy, with no real follow through.  English yeast..fruity/fishy.  Really quite an amateur production, not impressive as a US or UK ESB.  Sweetwater certainly seems more and more like a gimmicky brewery from the 90s.

On draught at the Sweetwater ATL bar. Pours a clear amber color with a medium thin and somewhat fizzy white head that evaporates steadily to a film. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and mild hops. Medium body with a sweet caramel malt character and notes of grassy hops and citrus. The finish is malty with a lingering sweetness left behind. Decent ESB overall.

Bottle shared by shigadeyo. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate floral hop and bitter malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.
Pours amber color with off white head. Aromas of caramel and floral hops. Sweet caramel flavor with some hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation.
Amber and slightly cloudy, Doesnt have the intricate malt bill that is require for this style. Bitter finish but harsh and plain.

Drinking this beer with 2 buddys with twindog and specfor found at the BBQ festival by bigguns22 at a food lion. Beer pours a dark amber with a little white to tan head. This beer has a Hugh caramel note , Very much reminds me of a dark lager but has a malty and hoppy note. First George beer, did not let us down.

Drinking this beer with 2 buddys with bigguns22 and specfor found at the BBQ festival by bigguns22 at a food lion. Beer pours a dark amber with a little white to tan head. This beer has a Hugh caramel note , Very much reminds me of a dark lager but has a malty and hoppy note. First George beer, did not let us down.

Drinking this beer with 2 buddys with bigguns22 and twin dog found at the BBQ festival by bigguns22 at a food lion. Beer pours a dark amber with a little white to tan head. This beer has a Hugh caramel note , Very much reminds me of a dark lager but has a malty and hoppy note. First George beer, did not let us down.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Habersham Liquors.  It pours a clear amber color with a small, foamy, light tan head.  The nose is slightly fruity and floral, a nice mix of malt and hops.  The flavor follows suit with some pine hops as well.  Some bread, fruitiness, and resin as the beer warms.  It reminds of a thinner SN Celebration for some reason.  Light to medium body with average carbonation and a medium to long, bitter finish.  Good stuff and recommended!

For the style, this is great, not just balanced, but the malt is really prominent, sweet and lots of caramel, but I am also getting some sharp astringent hops, bitter, but not too . This is Damn good, going to but it again.
Bottle. Tastes like a very tasty, mild IPA. Nice hoppy flavor with a floal taste. Golden, hay like color. Aroma is a pleasant hoppy smell.

Pours amber with small tan fizz. Smells sweet and malty but not excessively so. Tastes bitter, sweet, and mineraly. Medium-bodied with an earthy texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Sweetwater Motor Boat finishes with a mineral bitterness.

Pours an amber color with aromas of roasted nuts and caramel. Looks great with a foamy head. Taste starts with strong caramel sweetness followed by a grassy earthy mouthfeel with lingering sweet aftertaste like one just drank one of those wine coolers. Not pleasant and not recommended. If you like candy, youll like this beer. I kept searching for the bitter in this alleged ESB. Typical for Sweetwater...
Draft. Pours deep amber, medium white head. Pleasing floral and spruce aroma. Mild sweetness with medium-heavy bitter finish. Medium malt body, smooth, nice bitter overall.

Thus ESB has a nice clear copper color with an off-white/tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma of pine and grain w/some grapefruit. Clean, light to medium body w/ average carbonation. Very well balanced w/ some caramel sweetness, bread & and bitter hops throughout. A slightly dry finish. Delicious, with adequate complexity and very refreshing.
solid beer; thx John for bringing back from NC.  not much aroma for me but very good flavor - as others have stated - nice balance; right amounts of hops bittersweet at end; easy drinking beer

On tap at the Atlanta airport 
Appearance: Hazy amber with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, caramel and pine 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel and bitter pine 
Very nice, I like this one.

The aroma is nice with caramel, toffee, toasted malt, pine hops, and a touch of nutty yeast. The appearance is amber brown with a nice head that leaves lacing. The taste is like the aroma with a light bitter sweet finish. The palate is typical for the style. Overall this beer is pretty much an American interpretation of the style and pretty good as well but just doesnt seem that great.
Slightly cloudy orange pour with a compact white head. Caramel aroma typical of the style with some pine and citrus. Very bready, easy drinking with nice earthiness, although it finishes a bit dry.

12 oz. bottle from Secret Santa.  Thanks man!  Pours an orangish-red with a medium white head.  Aroma of toffee, caramel, and moderate spicy hops.  Flavor of caramel, bread, some sweet dough, with a mild leafy bitterness from the hops. Some notes of iced tea, crystal malt, and some dark breads.  Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  This is pretty nice to drink.

Bottle. Poured a slightly hazy dark orange color. The head was three fingers high  and light tan with good retention and lacing. Smelled of caramel and toffee with a whiff of dark fruit. Medium bodied and fairly sweet. Toffee, cola, caramel, and subdued citrus flavors.

An amber pour with an off-white head.  A malty, caramel aroma with some light floral notes.  The full body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste is mostly bitter, but also a little bready with a slightly dry finish.
12 oz bottle pours a orange/brown color with a medium white head.  Aroma of floral hops, with sweet malt.  Medium bodied with a slightly sweet finish

Received this from my Secret Santa KarrHeel03, thanks for the opportunity.
Pours a slightly hazy red orange color with a two finger fluffy beige head that persists forever. Smells of citrus right off, Im thinking grapefruit, but that aroma disappeared quickly. Some caramel and a bit of spicy, minerally esters waft up towards my nostrils as well. At first smell it was a dead ringer for an American IPA, but as it sat the nose definitely morphed into a more English bitter leaning animal. Taste is malty with caramel and brown bread, minerally with that English hop flair but an almost citrusy hop bite in there as well. Medium to high carbonation, medium body with a watery/syrupy mouthfeel. This is a weird little beer that I really enjoyed. Its like an Americanized version of an esb that is still true to its English roots.

12oz bottle. Rating #130. Medium copper pour with a decent white head. Light caramel aroma, no real sign of any good, nothing off though. Nice flavor, toasted light malts and a pretty smooth drinker. (1616)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: I really dont know how to describe these. Good mix of all a beer had to offer. Love my local brewery!!!

Appearance: orange and amber with a very slight haze. Maintains a solid pithy white collar, though little head to speak of.

Nose: hello hops; wet, sappy, and forestry. Intense orange skins oozing oils esters. Grassiness in the middle. Doughy breads slathered in orange marmalade with oranges baked inside. Honeycomb sweet and earthy. Pine trees in the back, needles and bark.

Palate: clean with a nice sticky hop leaf resiny bitterness. Pine bark and pine needs parlay with orange rind. Sweetness is much subdued, under and along the edges. Marmalade honeycomb up front on the tippy tip of tongue. Hop cones and pine asserts everywhere else.

Final Thoughts: quite brilliant with the hops while the doughy white breads sop it all up and before I know it, the glass is empty. A find solid year-round brew from Sweetwater.
(12oz bottle thanks to Cavie) clear rich orange with very few bubbles. Nose of candied orange, caramel, sweet grain. Taste is mildly bitter, rhubarb, orange juice and rye. Well carbonated oily body.
Orange-brown, little skunky, floral hops. Like a plain ale, not very distinctive taste, but not bad tasting.

Pours an amber orange with a small bubbly white head. Nose is citrus hops, caramel and some spice. Flavor is sweet malts and  balanced wonderfully with lots of citrusy hops. Bitter finish. One of Sweetwaters best beers.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma is lightly sweet and smells of malt, light nuts, Earth, and a hint of caramel.  Poured amber/orange in color with a large, creamy, off-white head that diminished but lasted thought.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is light to medium bitter.  Tastes of sweet malt, Earth, light hops, caramel, and nuts.  Medium body.  Slick, then dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Sweet, malt, Earth, caramel, and light nut finish is dry.

Thanks to Cavie for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours an orange-amber color with a cream-colored head. The aroma is toffee with some orange citrus hops. I also get a little bit of chocolate, which I was not expecting. The flavor is heavy on the toffee malt but there are some citrus hops to keep the beer nice and balanced. Low bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(12oz bottle, BB 12/20/10)  Pours a hazy orange body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, caramel, earth, and bread. Flavor of caramel malt, earthiness, grass, and citrus with a bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy drowland. Slightly cloudy orange color with light head. Aroma is slightly hoppy with some earthy malts. Flavor is dry with some sharp hops. Spiced. Finishes with the sweetwater standard flavor.
Definitely the best beer Ive had from Sweetwater; light citrus and moderate fresh cut lawn mix well with a nice, not overly sweet caramel malt body that is full.  Damn drinkable.
A good summer ale. I personally wouldnt buy a six pack but I would buy buy a couple every summer. Its an ale but nothing to write home about.

Draught at mellow mushroom, Birmingham. Amber pour with thin offwhite head. Faint aromas of sweet malt. Nice crisp maltiness up front with a hint of apricot sweetness. Medium hop bitterness with negligible hop flavor.
Pours a deep orange color, nose is floral, taste is mildly sweet, good bitterness, mild floral hop flavor, one of the best esbs Ive ever had.

Pour is a dark amber with a small tan head.  Aroma is earthy and alcohol.  Flavor is a decent earthy malt with nice hoppy backbone.  Finish is of heavy malts that leaves a caramel on the tounge.  A solid example of the style.

Hazy, dark, orange copper pour.  Thin off-white head that started off decent and dwindled down to a thin layer rapidly.  Light nose of pine and grapefruit pith.  Flavor is clean with resinous spruce, grapefruit and undertones of orange.  Finishes bitter with a lingering sappiness.  Subtle malty backbone to round out the flavor.  Very tasty and similar in taste to their IPA, without the excess malt.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with fata2683.  Pours a hazy burnished gold with a thin off-white head that faded to a film after one sip and left light lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt and overripe orange.  The flavor begins with malt along with just a bit of dried leaves.  This is followed by some mostly flavorless hops that add a bit of citrus pith bitterness that does not linger.  Medium bodied.  So so.

Thanks to Kirkpjr for this brew.

I poured this brew into my glass an produced a two finger off white head on top of a hazy amber colored. I was surprised to find more hops coming from this nose than there IPA.
There was a nice bitter flavor followed up with some sweet malts. This to me would be more hop forward than most ESB I have drank. It had good carbonation and I enjoyed drinking it. The problem I have with this brew was it meddled for the style. I just dont think it that true to a ESB. I guess thats why I dont judge at the GABF.

Serving type: bottle
bottle, clear amber color with strong frothy white foam, aroma is hoppy pineapples, falvor is bitter upfront with a sour hop lemony and caramel flavor, finish is  very dry fruit
Sample from bottle at the Treasure Coast Beer Fest 9/11/10 Ft Pierce, FL. Very good.

Got has an extra in a trade. Opened it and found a gusher, must have been a little shock up in shipping. The aroma is pretty malty, with a little bit of spice to it. The appearance is pretty dark with a thin off white head. The carbonation seems pretty good, as is the head retention. The mouthfeel is a little more then medium, but pretty easy to drink.

Bottle. Moderate malt and hop aromas of light bread, cereal and herbs and pine, light dough for the yeast, with background notes of raisin, dried cherry and brown sugar. Head is small, frothy, off-white with fair slippery lacing and is mostly diminishing. color is hazy red/tan. flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then the long finish is lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, a little slick with a lively carbonation and a slightly dry finish. well done, complex and well rounded. This is probably the best ESB Ive had to date.

Bottle. 12.17.2010 drink by date. Hazy dark amber color/ beige head. Sharp caramel, leafy hop aromas. medium bodied. Nice sweet n spicy caramel flavors with tea leaf hoppage. nicely bitter finish, good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
A: snifter. pours a slightly opaque tawny color. nice off-white head. low retention rate. nice ring-like lacing.

S: some sweet honey notes with some raisins, plums, and some light fig. some citrus as well.

T: good malty ESB, some spices, good fall fruits, apples, figs with some solid citrus notes from the hops.

M: good mouthfeel. light carbonation level. a little muddy.

D: very nice, I did expect a little more out of this though. A good ESB but nothing fantastic.

bottle pours amber with a medium light tan head, spotty lacing.  Nose is a mix of biscuit malt, rye, pine and floral hops.  Flavor is bread, doughy malt, toasted nuts, leafy hops with a resinous finish.  Nicely balanced ESB.

Clear cinnamon dunkelblonde beer with an oatmeal head.  Variant SweetWater label.  Soft, sweet, west coast hops and ale aroma.   Peppy, but not too hoppy.  Sweet, woody, chalky, great malting and balanced hopping.  Longish woody-hop finish with some grapefruit in the high palate.  Medium body.   The balance on this beer was fantastic - its not going to appeal to the high-gravity hophead, nor the Michelob Ultra fan, but its a good all-round brew.  ABC Liquors, Betton - From the SweetWater rep.

Bottle shared by Brian.  Thanks!  Pours clear brown color with off white head.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt brown sugar back bone.  It has that lager crispness in the nose.  Really nice.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is everything in the nose and finishes with a bitter twang that was unexpected and nice.  Probably one of my favorite lagers to date.  Good stuff.

Poured from 12oz bottle, has dark amber color with white head, has aroma full of malt and hops, it somehow has a flavor that is sweet and malty but yet has a nice bitter finish to it, very interesting and complex tasting beer, thanks drowland!

Appearance:  Pours a deep cloudy amber with a white head that subsides to an 1/8 inch of film.

Aroma: Bold citrusy pungent hops.

Taste: Lemony hops, brown sugar and tart red berry.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, juicy, with modest carbonation.

Overall:  Really good, seems more hoppy than previous years.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of my roommate. Pours a nearly transparent, dark copper color with a thin, but persistent, tan head. The aroma is mostly pine and citrus hops, with a little caramel and wheat. It is mostly bitter, with a good bit of malt balancing it well. The body is light to medium with some carbonation and fizziness. Nice, good flavor, and easy to drink.

This beer leads off with an amazing appearance; after what little white head there is subsides, youre left with a cloudy beer that has a gorgeous dark honey color that through most lights is reminiscent of a sunburst finish on a guitar. As you pour, the beer gives of a warm scent that becomes a very strong aroma of powerful but sweet hops as you put it up to your nose. The taste relies heavily on its bitter component for its flavor, hitting early and staying after youve swallowed. The beer is full bodied and lightly carbonated, leaving the impression of thickness after the beer is gone. Overall a very solid beer that I will be sure to have every time it is in season.

I feel very interested in this beer.  Half the time I like it, half the time I hate it.  Pours a hazy red/brown with a decent head.  The nose is all over the place.  Bread, copper, honey, citrus, and pine(?).  And it doesnt pull any punches with taste either.  Hits you with some sweet malt then finishes with floral hops.  I rated this one so highly not because I liked it so much, but because I kept going back for an extra sip to try to figure out whether I liked it or not.  Very interesting brew.

12oz bottle, best by Sept 29, 2010.  Pours hazy copper amber with a two finger off white head that holds well but doesnt leave much lacing.  Nice citrus and floral hop aroma balanced with some bread and caramel malts.  Flavor features caramel malt, dark bread, citrus and pine hops, medium sweetness and bitterness.  Very nice flavor.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, medium carbonation.  Never had an ESB before, however I can say this is one tasty and refreshing beer.  Nothing complex or extravagant, but thats not necessarily a bad thing.  Really enjoying this one, kudos Sweetwater!

Burnt orange in color... Aroma is biscuits, caramel malts... Hint of citrus hops aroma... Flavor is caramel malts, nice balance with just enough citrus hop bitterness... Good bitter finish... Nice beer

Bottle.  I had tried this a number of times before but waited til this years release to give it a proper review.  Pours a burnt orange with no head to speak of.  Aroma was of some caramel, bready malts and a good punch of citrus hops, Cascade right?  Aromas arent overpowering which I think fits the style well.  This is no doubt an Americanized version of an ESB.  Nice full mouthfeel, perfectly balanced use of malt and hops.  Great malty body with a lot of hop flavors to bring it back to earth.  Another good one from Sweetwater.

Appearance: Pours a reddish orange with a nice 2 finger off white foam head. Good head retention and nice lacing. So far so good.

Smell: Not much actually. Lots of bready biscuit like malt with some hops hiding in the background. My bottle says best before 12/8/08 (less than a month away) so Im sure it isnt the freshest bottle and that has contributed to the muting of the hops.

Taste: While I dont believe it is very traditional for the ESB style, Im really liking the taste of this brew. Mainly some toasty malts and some buttery qualities that lead into a palette flash of hops. Beer finishes with another dose of malt. Nice!

Mouthfeel & Drinkability: Good amount of carbonation and a slightly thin medium body makes this one go back like water.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2008
Leathery aroma, floral hops.  Tawny amber.  Nice burst of spicy hops over a caramel base.  My kind of ESB

12 oz. pours a cloudy bronzed medium ambrr with rubied edges and a nice creamy tan head that falls quickly away to not much. pleasantly mild peach and mango nose. creamy medium body, soft carb. caramel and toast mid palate. mild toasty finish.

Pours clear amber with a foamy light tan head. Aroma- sweet pine, grapefruit, toffee. Very sharp as far as hops for an ESB, definitely and American interpretation. Taste is moderately sweet with zesty, not so much bitter, but floral hops. Overall well balanced and light with a fullness of flavor.

My first thought when I opened this bottle was "Christmas tree/"  Piney, floral hops in the nose.  Orange amber color with a thin, off white head.  Malty sweetness, toffee and brown sugar, with some buttered toast, orange marmalade and soft grapefruit rind in the finish.  Thanks to craftbeerdesign for sending this very tastey beer.

Pours a copper color with an off white head and plenty of lacing.  Aroma of floral hops, toffee and malt.  Taste of nuts, malt, hops and toffee.  This is a very drinkable beer that I throroughly enjoyed.  One of my favorite Sweetwaters to date.

Sweetwater attempts a classic English style ESB with this one, and hits the nail on the head. Pouring a dark slightly cloudy amber, the nose is lightly fruity with a slight toffee. A nice two finger off-white head caps things off, and leaves behind ample lacing. Malty at first with hop character developing nicely towards the swallow, Motorboat is well balanced and could easily be misconstrued as a session beer, as it hides its 6.5% very well. The only hint is bit of warming on the way down. Well done for a style oft ignored in the US.
Golden brown pour. Nice thick bready taste with light hop pop on the back. Very smooth and drinkable if a tad thin.
Dark brown pour, off white head...Strong, hoppy aroma with a bit of sweetness...Nicely balanced, bit of malt breadiness with a mild hop finish...No bitterness...Excellent

Source:12 oz bottle from Frugal MacDoogals. 
Glass:Pint. 
Appearance:Hazy amber pour with half a finger of soapy white head.  
Aroma:Lots of citrus and some bready malt. 
Flavor:Grapefruit and resin with a hint of caramel and a bready finish. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:Excellent beer.  Another well made beer by Sweetwater.

Lighter brown color with a red tinge kind of like apple juice.  Completely white head and not much carbonation.  Small bubbles.  Taste is a lot like a pale ale, remnant of Sierra Nevada.  Pine and citrus nose, grapefruit that is so distinctly Sweetwater that disolves some after the swollow.  A great Autumn beer that is generous on the hops.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 12 oz bottle courtesy of GAManiac. Thanks, Grant! Pours a mellow darker amber, good haze, and sizable tannish head that stays moderate, laces pretty well. Aromas throw a lively citrus and floral hopping, lemon and grapefruit, a touch of orange marmalade moving into caramel and toasty toffee, nut, biscuits. Very nice. Initial is lesser side of medium bodied, toasty and caramel malts mingle with good citrus and floral hop, decent bitterness, orange marmalade and good solid maltiness that balances near perfectly with the hops, really pushing some orange at this point. Further into the body, juicy strawberry comes into play, very enjoyable. Finish is clean, decent bitterness and orange throwing in some toasty and sweet caramel malts. I really liked this ESB. Could use just a touch more body, but overall very good.
Hazy amber with a small beige head. Aroma had roasted malt, caramel and hoppy notes. Flavour was sweet and had quite a few hops, toasted malt and fruity notes. Finished bitter.

Bottled. A hazy dark amber beer with a thin lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of grapefruity hops, caramel, and citrus. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, bread, and grapefruit, leading to a dry bitter finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small tan head. Aroma is fruity and light pine wooden. Fruity and light sweet. Vague soapy mouthfeel and hops flavour. Fruity and subdued sweet flavoured into a medium dry finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of brentfeesh. Pours a hazy deep reddish amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of nuts and overripe fruit with some perfumy hops. Medium body, caramellish and nutty with very perfumy hops. No real bitterness. Highly drinkable. 111009

12 ounce bottle from Sams Quik Shop in Durham, NC. Pours a hazy copper color with a medium sized head. Good head retention and lacing. Sticky citrus and floral hop aroma. Taste is bitter citrus hops with lots of pineapple and peach notes. Very faint caramel that grows a bit in the finish. Medium bodied.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a amber color with a large off white head. It has a wonderful burnt caramel and biscuit taste along with a toffee taste. The hop and malt flavors complement each other very well. I really enjoyed this beer.

Piney hops on the nose, resin with caramelly malt in the background.  Pours amber with a thin white head.  Very smooth, not as hoppy as it smells, caramelly sweet malts with spicy grassy hop notes.  Pretty good!

Bottle. Small white head on a burgandy colored beer. Delicious nose of fresh hops. Flavors quite hoppy as well, extremely fresh tasting with a bit of a caramel base. Finishes crisp and clean. A little more of an IPA in my opinion, but regardless of the style, its good stuff. (Bonus points for a good price and funny name)

On tap at BW3 Tallahassee.  Dark amber pour with a nice off white head.  Has a nice earthy hop aroma, but a little faint.  Outstanding flavor,nice underlying bitterness with just enough sweetness.  I think I have a new beer of choice at my favorite bar.
Pours a dark amber color with a minimal head. Aroma of malts and some floral hops. Flavor is of pine hops with some malts and a very stong caramel finish.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Proof - on tap. Dark copper pour, nice off white head, good lacing. Hard to place aroma, some faint fruit, floral notes. Flavor is malt-dominated with some nuttiness, bits of chocolate, underlying subtle bitterness. Mouthfeel is nice and full. Decent.
Draft at ATL airport tap. Nice dark amber red with a nice sticky top.  Pleasant tacky, citrusy appeal, with a big malt backbone. Chewy even. Excellent. (#3659, 8/8/2009)

On draught at the High Country Beer Fest, it pours deep amber, with a nice head leaving generous lace.  Biscuity notes, with hints of copper, some light malt backing and a nice bitter floral finish.  The palate is lively, with good carbonation.  Nice, full-bodied mouthfeel with a smooth texture.  Extremely well-balanced offering.  Very nice ESA, and best categorized as such.  There are hints here of an ESB, but the complexities push it to the ESA category appropriately.  Nice job!

Twelve ounce bottle pours a hazy amber body with a two finger almond head. Abundant lacing is left on the glass. Aroma is like an IPA, with sharp citrusy grapefruit and pine notes. Taste follows suit, with a prominent citrusy hop bitterness edged by pine notes. No malt presence. This would be a decent IPA but falls short of being an ESB.

This may be my favorite Sweetwater. For a non-English ESB, its really pretty good. The hops flavor is a bit more pervasive than the malt, but the malt makes a great base layer. The taste is somewhat citric with a caramel undertone.
Pours a clear, deep copper body with a lasting ring of beige head.  Smells of floral hops, touch of roast, toffee.  Flavor is the same.  Not too bitter.  I like the hops used in this brew.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Amber red pour. Huge fresh hop aroma with a touch of malt.  The flavor is nice fresh hop with a hint of sweet malt backing.  Nice beer.  Also tried on tap at the airport.  Very similar, both versions must have been fresh.

12 oz. bottle from a 6-pack. Purchased at Greens on Ponce De Leon. Nice dark copper/caramel brown. Beer is dark but still transparent. Used to be listed as an ESB, but not it is an ESA? Oh well, the beer looks good nonetheless. Nice head that settles to a nice thin head that doesnt seem to disappear. Very nice sweet malty aroma with a strong hop backing. Very aromatic floral aroma. This beer surprisingly has exceeded my expectations in terms of aroma. Nice malty flavor with a nice subtle hop backing. Hops leave a lingering but subtle bitterness in your mouth. I could be wrong but I taste a subtle toffee flavor at the beginning which quickly fades away to that sweet malty and hop flavor. Very balanced beer, as many of you have noted. I actually enjoyed this one...pretty good and fairly smooth.

12 oz. bottle of sweetwaters most recent release.  amber.  Aroma starts this beer off strong, soft and sweet flowery / honey hops, nice off white lingering head,  taste of nutty rich hoppy malts.  i guess you can tell from the way im writing this this beer is BALANCED.  very smooth and could drink em all day.
12 oz bottle at Ians  Very nice tasting. Has sweet hints and nice hoppy smell.  Hope to get more of it.

[1858-20081112] 12floz bottle. Grassy hops aroma. Clear, amber red body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Mild bitter grainy hops flavour with mild leafy grasses and mild oldness. Medium body is a little dry. Average, drinkable.
(c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc)

Bottle courtesy of kp: Pours a transparent deeo copper amber with a large, well-lacing froth of off-white head.  Aroma of nice grapefruity and lemony hops with a good caramel malty presence.  Starts fairly full for the style with pleasant toffee sweetness and good piny flavoring hop balance before a crisp, bittersweet finish.  Probably more like an amber than an ESB, but enjoyable nonetheless.

12oz bottle thanks to....  Pours amber with a reddish tint.  Has a thin, off-white head.  My sinuses were clogged so I couldnt tell what this smelled like.  Taste had some caramel malt.  Mouthfeel was medium-to-light woth some mild bitterness.  Not bad.
Bottle shared by wolf-man! Amber red in color, decent little head... Sweet malty taste, but kept its balance. Really easy to drink. I enjoyed this beer. Overall...impressed

Poured a clear deep copper color with a thin off-white head. Fruity aroma with oranges and a moderate amount of sweet caramel malt.  Light hops.  Caramel malt flavor that starts sweet but has a dry finish.  Earthy notes.  Mild to moderate bitterness.  Light to a medium body.

2008-11-12. Dark amber with a modest beige head. (3+) Mild muted hops in the aroma. (6+) Mild bitterness and hops throughout in the flavour, light tangy bitterness. Very light dry fruit undertones. Average palate. Nearing its twilight. Bottle shared by DuctTape

Thanks to Daknole for the bottle.  Drank on 12/20, label says best if enjoyed by 12/21, haha just in the nic of time.  Pours an orange amber with a small white head, that dissipates into small bubbles.  Aromas of some dark fruits, cherries and lots of caramel malts.  Flavors up front are sweet malts, and caramel.  The finish is more malt, and very little hops, and very little bitterness.

12 oz bottle-trade w/daknole-amber pour w/a slight head & good lacing. Hoppy aroma. Tastes more like a standard amber ale than a English Strong, has a little bit of a hop bite to it, some roasted malt. Not bad, but not spectacular. Long bitter finish

Bottle, bought at Bierloods. Thx to vacas.
A clear copper-amber color with medium off-white head.
 Aroma hoppy, full mouthfeel and some bitter. Medium body.
Taste good bitter hoppy, little spice, with some malts sweetness and warming finish.
Good one.

Bottle shared by emacgee. Thanks Ethan. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a small bubbled white lace. Nose is slightly hoppy, with some honey and sweet malt.  Flavor shows some depth in the hops. Apricot, peach, earthy hops surround the malts. Better than I expected.

bottle from Greens in Atl.  Amber/red pour.  Small light head that disappears fast.  Aroma is malty, honey, caramel malt and maybe a slight hint of hops.  Flavor is bready, honey notes and some good hop bitterness.

12 ounce bottle from emacgee.  Pours dark red with plenty of tan head the leaves some nice lace.  The nose is bready and pretty sweet with an earthy hop character.  The flavor is balanced with slightly over cooked biscuits with a touch of jam, and earthy and herbal hop bitterness.  Fuller body and a bit sticky.  Balanced finish.  Certainly enjoyable.
Dark reddish-brown with a thin off white head that settles to a cover.  Aroma of sweet candy, caramel and toffee.  Strong bitter malts, mostly sweet with a good hoppy earthy bitterness.
Poured cloudy amber. Lightly hoppy aroma. Taste - Earthy, grassy hops, caramel and some malt to balance it out. Not too bitter.
Dark brown pour.  A bit sweet for my taste.  Seems fairly true to the style, but would love a little more b with my esb.

btl opened by springslicker. Deep amber pour with a creamy white head and lace. Caramel and brown sugar with medium hops. Medium caramel flavor and a medium citrus bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation. A very nice beer.

Medium head, halfway mango-amber, dense, over very slightly hazed darker orange-amber beer. Grape/raisins cake with hoppy & lytchee aromas. Hops, but especially leafy/earthy flavours. Bitterness comes after a general sweetish-malty impression. Bit fiery MF, not very well-bodied. Palate falls a bit dead, leaving only indifferent bitterness. Beautiful nose, great flavours, but average finish.
Bottle courtesy of daknole. Pours copper with a nice white head. Smells of caramel and sweet malt. Tastes of pepper, caramel, spice, some earthy compliments on the finish.

Poured to a bright copper color with medium off-white head that lingered thru mid glass and left okay lacing. Aroma was hoppy citrus and the mouthfeel full and slightly bitter. Taaste was a follow-up of the bitter hoppy citrus, with an undertoen of malty sweetness at midglass. Rounded to a nice, full warming finish, with just the right amount of dryness.

Good effort Sweetwater!

Thanks to Ian for the bottle. Pours a nice reddish brown with a thin white head. Citrus hop and caramel malt aroma. Nice medium thick body with lots more caramel malt and big citrus hops hops. Tasty and easy to drink.

Pours a red orange copper with a one finger frothy off white head. The nose is sweet, citrusy hops, pretty pungent, has a nice (American) hop character laid over a prominent malt character. The flavor is sweet, citrusy hops, hop presence, malty, orange peel, light bitterness, lightly subdued. The palate is thin waxy with a light body.

Caramel apples in the nose with some with slight resin.  Brilliant light amber in color with a nice off-white head.  Juicy caramel mixes with noble hops to give some citric twang.  Long, balanced finish.  A great beer!

12oz bottle.  Clear amber pour with a light head.  Nice smelling ESB.  English hops are right there for your enjoyment as is a pleasant malty grain.  Probably the best tasting ESB in some time as well.  Well balanced malts, grain flavors, and English earthy hops (maybe a touch of citrus as well) mixed well with a bit of sweetness.  Very nice.  Medium semi-dry body.  If I was going to brew one, this would be it.

pours dark brown and has a light hop aroma.Very light texture which I didnt expect due to the 6.5% abv.slight sweetness and just a hint of bitter / hops.This beer is way drinkable / goes down easy and smooth.I could easily have a few of these.

Aroma is strong and malty with a firm hoppy undertone and a decided hint of molasses. Color is a beautiful, clear, appetizing copper with an off-white and fairly persistent head. Mouth-filling flavor is fairly but not fiercely bitter, and has just a whisper of sweetness as well as a nutty undertone. Texture is exceptionally smooth so it goes down very nicely.

12 oz. bottle via trade with kp - Pours a hazy deep amber color with a one and a quarter finger thick off white head.  There is a light amount of floaties in there too.  Light lacing.  Aroma is toasted toffee, floral hops, and oranges.  Flavor is toasted malt, esters, and floral hops.  Palate is fairly smooth.  Medium body.  The oranges show up again just a tad bit in the aftertaste.  A pretty nice, easy drinking beer.  Thanks Keith.

Thanks to goldtwins for sharing.  Pale orange-amber colour.  Aroma is fairly sweet with a lot of crystal malt sweetness.  A sort of orange peel and light caramel aroma.  Herbal hoppiness that doesn’t quite round off the sweet edges of this beer.  Oranges and a bit of cherry as well.  A light attempt at dusty bitterness.  It’s on the sweet side, but it works pretty well.
good stuff, nice taste, nice coloring, taste like a good beer. rock star taste

Burnt orange color was nice to look at, and the body was mostly clear with some lingering haze.  The head was thin, like a rim of bubbles mostly.  The smell was sweet and citric, and nothing like any ESB.  It was too fruity and perfumey to be considered even close.  The taste was spicy, earthy, honey sweet, and slightly soured.  The mouthfeel was very chalky and a bit harsh.  Not a bad beer per se, but way off target for the style, and not very sessionable.

Pours a clear copper with a good head. There’s a nice brown sugar and wood malt in the aroma backed by a moderate hop character. Satisfyingly malty, just enough hops to balance. This makes for a really nice football beer.

Date: 09/05/2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Bullock’s

Appearance: clear red, fine beige head, 
Aroma: dry caramel malt aroma with lots of earthy hops, bready character, 
Flavor: rich malt flavor, caramel and bready characters, lots of earthy hops keep it pretty dry, just a hint of caramel sweetness in the end, long bitter finish, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: *4
clear amber pour pour with a frothy white head and decent lace.  Grapefruit aroma.  Earthy hops flavor balanced out with sweet caramel malts.   Lingering bitter finish

12oz bottle, Best if enjoyed by 11/23/08, thanks Grant (GAManiac).  Clear brown copper with a small beige head, fading to a film and ring.  Aroma of biscuity malts, decomposing fall leaves, and some soft pine.  Hints of matallic notes as well.  Flavor is just a bit more piny and some added earthy caramel notes, and all the other aromas follow suit.  This beer only gets a little sweet, and finishes dry with bitterness peaking around a 3.  Light soft carbonation with a medium body.  This was a very pleasant surprise.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Finally getting to this one. Nice beer, a little too high powered to be a session beer but still tasty.  Pours clear brown with a minimal off white head. Nice hop aroma. Profile is a little different for these guys and a little more well balanced. Nice piney and grapefruit hop smells but also some caramel malt and candy.  Flavor is medium bodied slightly resiny, sticky, hops and caramel. Bitter finish to set you on your way.
Light brown/dark amber with a little off white head. Taste is mainly malts and a bit sweet. Light bitterness in finish to round it off. This would make a pretty decent session beer.

12oz bottle.  reddish brown pour with a medium tan head that disappears quickly.  aroma of earthy floral hops and caramel malts.  clean bitter taste - caramel, light citrus, roasted malts.  light to medium texture.  good stuff.
12oz from kpresely77.  Pours dark amber with barely any head.  Nose is sweet and malty.  Taste is big and malty, with a bit of caramel sweetness.  Pretty good.

Clear amber under an off-white head.
Malty, pine hop aroma.
Piney, dry and smooth.

An amber apperance with a beige head. The aroma really doesnt jump out at you and contains some caramel and a hint of citrus. The flavor is somewhat sour but most malty with some caramel, citrus flavors such as lemons and oranges. Overall this was a pretty good beer.

Seems to be somewhere between an ESB and aan English style IPA, with a lot of earthy malt and piney hops in the finish. Looks nice, though, all reddish copper and such. Seems kind of rough and unrefined, in a good way.

Sample draft from Brewgrass.  I guess this is a strong ESB?  It’s quite hoppy, not quite as bitter as I’d expect from an ESB--almost IPA-like--but perhaps that’s the "strong" part of it; not quite as fruity as an IPA.  More malt to it  Biscuity.  Dark amber pour.  Pretty, pretty, pretty good.

Interesting, this says english strong ale, yet the bottle says ESB.  I guess Sweetwater needs to start learning exactly what they are brewing.  Pours a nice darker coppy color with a decent beige head.  aroma is citrusy and fruity.  Flaovr is very much the same with a nice hop finish to it.  overall a great beer.

Bottle generously shared with NachlamSie, thanks man. (Best before November 23rd, 2008.) Pours a translucent copper with an off-white head. The aroma is heavy in hops. Tons of grapefruit-like citrus with dry grassy notes. Subtle malty notes linger behind the intense hoppy aroma. The malts are very noticeable in the flavour, though. The initial flavour is of sweet biscuits and toffee with a light hoppy dryness and bitterness. As the brew passes the tongue, the hops quality matches the malts and creates a very nice balance. Citrus also becomes more evident. The finish is only slightly dry. But the malty qualities keep it a little on the smoother side. This is quite delicious.

Bottle best before November 23, 2008. Pours a dark copper with a decent head. The aroma is rather hoppy. I get quite a bit of American leaning notes in the nose such as grapefruit, but everything mellows out to a certainly English vibe with hints at toffee and biscuits, maybe some wooden bitterness. The palate is a little thinner than I was expecting, but it’s smooth and pleasing nonetheless. Definite English malts on this one with toffee, burning leaves, and buttered biscuits. The hops are much more apparent in the aroma, though they add a decent level of dryness to the flavor. Sweetwater is awesome. They have the right attitude, the right names, and the product to back it up. This take on an ESB really reminds me of a tasty homebrew of Joe’s. U.S. meets U.K. in a very tasty fashion.

Bottle courtesy of Springslicker. (Best by 12/07/08) Poured cooper with an off-white head that settles to a ring. Nice orange peel and caramel aroma. The flavor finds a grapefruit and caramel balance. Medium body, medium bitterness throughout. Smooth and enjoyable.

Bottle in trade from RustyDiamond.  Thanks!

Pours a nice amber clear color with a beige head.  Smell is mildy nutty, dusty, fruity and tea like malt, all nicely balanced with none overpowering another.  Taste is the same lightly nutty and dusty malt with some lightly bitter fruitiness to balance.  Fruity gummy flavor as well.  Very drinkable and a nice clean ESB.  Thanks for this one!

Bottle from Jay.  Pours out a brown color with a nice tan head on it.  Smell is fruity, malty, and then all of a sudden there is a nice smack of hops right in there.  Really this beer smells way better than it tastes.  Taste is sweet and fruity, easy to drink even for the 6.5% - I would consider this a session beer.  Flavor has some grass and citrus notes which is awkward for an English Strong Ale.  Good beer though, one of the best of our lager starts.

Draft at Taco Macs Kennesaw location, and a 12 oz. bottle a few days later. Mostly clear, dark copper with a nice two-finger head that leaves nice lace. Earthy orange-resin and caramel nose. Hoppy flavors of tea leaf, orange-grapefruit and resin are almost balanced by some caramel, roasted nut and cocoa. Medium body is smooth and slightly dry with a light hop tingle. Excellent ESB.

Oxidationfest Tasting at illinsmitty’s.  Pours a reddish hued clear, with big bubbled, fading white head.  Earthy and floral hop nose, piney, reminds me of simcoe without the cat piss.  Flavor balances out toward the malty but a hop bite in the finish.  Didn’t think as highly of this as everyone else apparently.

Bottle from Springslicker. Pours a nice copper amber with a light beige retentive head. Nice fruity ester nose, sort of orangey. Lighter side of medium bodied. Flavor of caramel and grains, with some citrusy accents. Very moderate balancing bitterness.

Pours a stunning reddish/orange with a thick white/yellowish head.  Smells of strong hops just adds to my anticipation.  First sip is bitter and clean – surprisingly not as hoppy as the lovely aroma would indicate.  Mouthfeel is good but this puppy could use a stronger malt backbone.  A fine showing from Sweetwater.

Bottle pours beautiful clear amber with thin quick diminishing white head. Aroma is faint pine hops. First taste is sweet with nice balance and slight pine hops finish. Not overpowering on hops. The mouthfeel is watery with light carbonation. One of the better Sweetwater products.

bottle.  pours a deep amber with a 1/4"; white head.  mild hops in the aroma along with some light bread.  extremely smooth over the palate... nice and bitter from front to back - with the highest concentration on the roof of the mouth.  soft, gentle sides and a short finish.  the most enjoyable aspect of this beer is the smoothness over the palate - it is almost like butter at times.  Overall a solid beer from Sweetwater... more interesting than Road Trip, but not quite as exciting as some of their others.

Copper/amber pour with a nice, frothy and lasting white head.  Aroma is enticing with a doughy/bisquit malt nose with quite a bit of citrus/piney hops.  Mostly malty flavor with some caramel, burnt toast, bisquit and some warming alcohol from start to finish.  Also some pretty strong hoppage, citrus and pine and the finish has a lingering sweetness and pine.  Tasty tasty tasty!

12 oz. bottle purchased at Total Wine in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a reddish-amber body with a small, frothy, ivory-colored head.

Smell: Aroma smelling strongly of spice and plump citrus fruits overlaying lighter notes of day-old, over-cooked biscuits.

Taste: Toasted biscuits with a touch of grain and even less caramel sweetness. Taste of citric grapefruit, maybe a few berries in there as well. Spicy, citrus hops with a medium bitterness. Sugar hints come and go throughout. Finishes dry, with an herbal quality to the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: Some pair up beers with fine cuisine, maybe some even pair up beers with music. Me, I set beers up alongside movies. This bitter brew contrasted nicely to the sweet, satisfying ending of Karate Kid when Daniel defeats Whatshisname from Cobra Kai. Although the bitterness comes rushing back when I see Karate Kid 2 is up next.

12oz bottle. Pours a brilliant copper with hints of soft pinkish amber and a medium-sized, off-white head that leaves beautiful streaks and spots of lace on the glass as it goes down. The aroma is a nice balance of spicy hops with subtle citrus and sweet, honey-covered croissants. The flavor follows the nose: a nice spicy, evergreen hop note combined with delicious, sweet, caramel malts. Flavor has some nice notes of toasted bread and hints of earthiness in that delectable bitterness. At mid-tongue, the flesh is tickled by the wonderful, spicy, bitter hops and carbonation - a subtle sting that is sweet to the touch. The finish is malty and also nicely hoppy. The mouthfeel is medium in body and well-carbonated, but overly carbonated - just right for style (which is American Amber I’d say, not ESB). Overall, a really magnificently balanced, drinkable, delicious American Amber. I have fond memories of Sweetwaters old ESB (their staple before 420 took off as their flagship). They no longer make ESB, but this makes me think fondly of it again - despite the fact that it isnt likely anything like it and is probably much, much better (its been years since they stopped making the ESB, so I cant really remember...the original ESB may have been more like... well, an ESB). Quite a treat.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep, clear amber color.  Thin, off white head.  Decent amount of lacing.  Wonderful hoppy aroma.  Flavor is pefectly balanced between the bready malts and the floral hops.  Long bitter finish.  This is one gem of a beer.  Great job Sweetwater for this Catch & Release.

Pours a deep copper red color with a white head. Aroma is malty, toasty, rasins,crystal malts,biscuit, and some earthy notes. Flavor is malty, caramel, rasins, some crystal sweetness, toast, and a bitter earthy finish.

12oz bottle.  Deep ruby red, off-white head.  Beautiful.  Smells great.  Nice west coast c-hop aroma, lots of chocoate malt in the nose as well.  Super tasty.  Flavor of caramel, some bread, chocolate, and some distant cotton candy sweetness.  Finishes with a superb bitterness.  Nice touches of gratefruit.  I let a non-beerdrinker take a sip.  she took two and loved it.  This may be the most impressed I’ve been with a Sweetwater offering since having 420 for the first time in the 90s!

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 Really red.  One of the reddest beers Ive seen.  Great color.  The small head is cream colored.  Very hoppy aroma, full of centennial or cascade type hops.  Good malt backbone.  Reminds me of their IPA a bit, but with more of a caramel flavor.  Good job.

Re-rate.  Had to add some points.  Great beer.  Comments above stand, just decided it was worthy of a higher score.

motor boat pours a clear rusty amber with no lacing under a frothy yellowish head and bits of sediment floating around.  sweet shortbread cookie, cake, candy-like aroma with floral hops.  excellent balance with the sugared-cookie-bready-21st birthday cake malts and floral hops in flavor.  medium bodied, smooth and dangerously drinkable...damn.  way better than the last catch and release creation "road trip".

Pours copper with a small white head, no lace.  Aroma is pretty nice, with bready malt and light hops.  Taste is a little more subdued, in my opinion, with light hops and more of the bread malt.  Finish isn’t all that bitter.  Mouth is medium-bodied and carbonation is light.  Overall, a nice brew with a nice aroma, though not all that bitter or memorable.

Pours a light, clear copper with a very short-lived off-white head that leaves a very thin ring and no lacing at all. The smell is very light with biscuity malts and a hint of earthy hops on top. The taste is a bit bigger than the aroma and starts with a kick of grassy hops up front before giving way to a slightly sweet bready malt background. The finish is dry with a little bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium with light to moderate carbonation, very crisp and dry in the finish. The drinkability is fairly high on this with the bitterness being pretty subtle. All in all, a decent effort from Sweetwater and Im hoping they continue to branch out in the near future.
